mustsees.desc: Bali celebrates its own Independence Day on August 17th with a colorful parade. Best spot to see the parade is its Northern capital Singaraja - it’s a couple of hours long, very cheerful event and since Singaraja is not the most touristy town you’re likely to be celebrating it like a local.
mustsees.title: Bali Independence Day parade in Singaraja

badges.desc: While $10-$20 accommodation in the largest towns in still possible to find, booking is advised, otherwise on arrival you might have to walk around for a while in order to find a suitable place to stay. Accommodation and transportation costs generally grow about 30% in high season.

South of Bali will be really crowded, especially around Kuta. This is the time when the risk of getting scammed is at its peak. Beware of overly friendly locals who offer you “a great holiday deal” - timeshare scam is popular. Money exchange is another concern - do it in certified places only - you can count your changed money several times, but you’re still likely to walk out with at least 10% of it missing (the trick is a very special cashier table with a crack in it)

This is the time when water around the South is very clear - perfect for snorkeling and diving. Get out of the mainland and visit one of the smallest islands South of Kuta (e.g. Lembongan) or islands around Lombok and you will enjoy the best of what the underwater world can offer. In comparison to many advertised snorkeling spots in Thailand, the reef around Bali is still very alive.

mustsees.desc: Tawur Kesanga, Balinese New Year’s Eve is a celebration full of color and ritual. Visit a village or a rural community to witness families and community members gathering together and making offerings.
mustsees.title: Tawur Kesanga or Ogoh-Ogoh day

badges.desc: Rain season is not as bad in Bali as in other parts of South East Asia since it’s not likely to rain all day and every day. You need to consider though that some beach and water activities might get canceled - e.g. snorkeling, dolphin watching, beach parties. Hotel/guest house prices will drop pretty dramatically. If you want to find real relaxation and tranquility vs. toasting your butt on the beach - this time is great for staying in sleepy villages and misty hills.

Even though the risk of Malaria and Dengue fever is relatively low in Bali, use mosquito nets whenever you’re staying in rural areas and get a good mosquito spray to use after dusk (you can buy the spray in almost every shop)

mustsees.desc: Get out and see the fireworks on the beach - you will not regret the show!
mustsees.title: New Year fireworks

badges.desc: Rain season is not as bad in Bali as in other parts of South East Asia since it’s not likely to rain all day and every day. You need to consider though that some beach and water activities might get canceled - e.g. snorkeling, dolphin watching, beach parties.

Even though the risk of Malaria and Dengue fever is relatively low in Bali, use mosquito nets whenever you’re staying in rural areas and get a good mosquito spray to use after dusk (you can buy the spray in almost every shop)

Despite the rain many people still choose to spend their Christmas and New Year in Bali. It does rain most of the time, but cozy accommodation and party vibe will make up for the rain. Many hotels and guest houses in the South will update their prices for Christmas and New Year based on high/peak season standards, so expect higher costs than in any other rainy month.
